elements.title: Austin J. Tobin Plaza (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Austin J. Tobin Plaza (pictured) was destroyed in the September 11 attacks, but one of the sculptures on it survived?

elements.title: Motibai Kapadia (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in 1884 Motibai Kapadia's father allowed her to study alongside men in India?

elements.title: steam tug Brent (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in the late 1940s the steam tug Brent removed war-related debris, including naval mines, from the River Thames?

elements.title: Lorena Peril (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Lorena Peril, who once cleaned toilets at a nursing home, beat out over 3,000 people to sing the national anthem for the San Francisco 49ers?

elements.title: died following a dog attack (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Mohammad Bhar, a Palestinian man with Down syndrome and autism, died following a dog attack in the Gaza Strip during the Israel–Hamas war?

elements.title: The Eternaut (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Héctor Germán Oesterheld repurposed his initial plans for a sequel of the comic The Eternaut as a novel?

elements.title: Helen Hornbeck Tanner (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Helen Hornbeck Tanner was part of a major case supporting the Ojibwe before the Supreme Court of the United States while in her 80s?

elements.title: Wolfman's Got Nards (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the title of the documentary Wolfman's Got Nards is derived from a memorable line in the 1987 film The Monster Squad?

elements.title: Jajaira Gonzalez (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that USA Boxing's head coach said that Olympian Jajaira Gonzalez's return to boxing was "like Lazarus coming back from the dead"?
